text:
Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann ReardonÂ 
and this is a new episode of CAKE RESCUEÂ Â

where I take viral cake fails from across theÂ 
internet and social media and show you how toÂ Â

rescue them. Let's start with shaped cake tins,Â 
these look deceptively simple but sometimes theÂ Â

shape doesn't turn out ... not great ... and evenÂ 
if it does you then need the skills to frost it.Â Â

Let's recreate the fail and then go from there.Â 
Now I've hired a Thomas the tank engine tin fromÂ Â

my local cake decorating store theyÂ 
usually have a range of tins there.Â Â

I've sprayed it really well with cooking oilÂ 
so i'm fairly confident it will turn out.Â Â

Once it's baked you just need to level off theÂ 
top put a cooling rack on it and flip it overÂ Â

and take off the tin that looks great now letÂ 
that cool. Now wilton has instructions on howÂ Â

to decorate their character cakes which involvesÂ 
piping an outline in black and then coloring itÂ Â

in by piping little star shapes all over theÂ 
cake which i think works well for things thatÂ Â

are furry like dogs and those sort of things butÂ 
not necessarily well on some other charactersÂ Â

and if you don't like the star-shaped look andÂ 
you just spread frosting flat over the whole cakeÂ Â

you've lost the position of all the details you'reÂ 
pretty much just starting from scratch so you'reÂ Â

a bit stuck. I think that we are now at the stageÂ 
that they are so let's rescue this cake. Grab yourÂ Â

tin and print out a picture of what your characterÂ 
is supposed to look like now pipe on the detailsÂ Â

using candy melts or compound white chocolateÂ 
colored with an oil-based food coloring. The greatÂ Â

thing about piping directly onto the tin is ifÂ 
you make a mistake you can wipe it off or you canÂ Â

neaten up your lines if you go crooked or becauseÂ 
it's chocolate you can wait until it's starting toÂ Â

set and then remove the bit you don't want so theÂ 
eyes on the picture i have have a white bit at theÂ Â

top so i'm just taking a little bit of the blackÂ 
chocolate off. Then add some white on top and seeÂ Â

how i accidentally dropped some there i can justÂ 
wipe that off. To get smooth round edges pipe itÂ Â

a bit smaller than you need and then come in withÂ 
the back of a spoon and just jiggle the chocolateÂ Â

to spread it out to the edge a little bit that'sÂ 
much easier than trying to pipe it perfectly.Â Â

Layer it up with the other colorsÂ 
that you need for your characterÂ Â

and then pour in the last color. Now this isÂ 
going to be a thick layer of chocolate on top ofÂ Â

the cake but it's a cake rescue and i don't thinkÂ 
anyone will complain when they eat it ğŸ˜You're justÂ Â

going to need a really hot knife to cut throughÂ 
it. Now put the cake with the frosting into theÂ Â

cake tin that's lined with chocolate, level offÂ 
the top and put a board on top and now flip itÂ Â

over ... now the moment of truth i have neverÂ 
actually done this before i just thought thisÂ Â

might work as a rescue so let's see, positioningÂ 
it on the board where you want it to beÂ Â

i think that looks pretty straight what do youÂ 
think and then carefully take off the tin...

It worked really well it worked betterÂ 
than i thought it would actually!Â Â

How's that for a thomas cake rescue? TheÂ 
smoothness actually suits this train cakeÂ Â

really well better than piped stars would anywayÂ 
it's not perfect it's a little bit broken here onÂ Â

the bottom but it is a rescue you could use someÂ 
extra chocolate to fix that if you wanted to.Â Â

Now before we move on to the next cake I haveÂ 
a BIG announcement to share with you which IÂ Â

hope you will love â¤ï¸ I have been busy writing aÂ 
cookbook for you! I've been working really hard onÂ Â

this over the last year and it will be availableÂ 
very soon, you can pre-order your copy now, justÂ Â

search for Ann Reardon on Amazon or most otherÂ 
bookstores and you'll find it. I'll put a linkÂ Â

to it below as well and I've got lots of fun extraÂ 
stuff for people who pre-order and competitionsÂ Â

and stuff like that coming up soon, so make sureÂ 
you're watching future videos for those ğŸ‰Moving onÂ Â

to cake fail number two ... the island cake. IfÂ 
you haven't seen this cake before it's supposedÂ Â

to look like an island and the jelly bit shouldÂ 
be a clear bluey green that you can see through.Â Â

Now the first thing that can go wrong of courseÂ 
is the jelly or jello not setting let me know inÂ Â

the comments what you call it here in AustraliaÂ 
we call this jelly. If you make it up accordingÂ Â

to the directions on the packet and let it setÂ 
in the fridge overnight when it's in a containerÂ Â

it's fine because it has the support of the edgesÂ 
of the container but if we try and tip that outÂ Â

well we've left half of the jelly in the jug butÂ 
beside that if you try and imagine this as a tallÂ Â

cake in this texture it's just not firm enough toÂ 
hold its shape. Whatever gelatin or jelly you useÂ Â

you need to use one and a half times the amountÂ 
that it says you need to set the volume of waterÂ Â

that you've got. So let's quickly make an islandÂ 
cake fail and then show you how to rescue itÂ Â

spread some ganache on the board it's importantÂ 
that that goes underneath the cake so the cakeÂ Â

doesn't go soggy add some cake on and then stackÂ 
it up on one side you can choose whatever shapeÂ Â

you want it really doesn't matter you could useÂ 
this to rescue another cake fail that's just aÂ Â

mess of cake. carve it to look less like cakeÂ 
and more like rocks and you can put the offcutsÂ Â

on top to make it higher and then cover that wholeÂ 
thing in ganache. I'm using some different coloredÂ Â

ganache some milk chocolate one here just to add aÂ 
bit of variation you can leave that off or do thatÂ Â

it's up to you and then put that in the fridge.Â 
For the jelly i'm using sheets of gelatin becauseÂ Â

the sheets set clearer than your powdered gelatinÂ 
and you can see here with the store-bought jellyÂ Â

you can't see through it and we want it to beÂ 
able to be clear enough to see through. Let theÂ Â

sheets soak to soften and as i said before use oneÂ 
and a half times the amount it says you need forÂ Â

the volume of water that you're setting becauseÂ 
you need it to hold its shape without supportÂ Â

then in a pan you want water sugar and flavoringÂ 
of your choice and then heat it until the sugarÂ Â

is dissolved which won't take long and then add inÂ 
the gelatin sheets and they should just melt away.Â Â

Add a tiny bit of color at a time now i'veÂ 
made this color using blue a little bit ofÂ Â

green and the tiniest bit of red just to giveÂ 
it the right sort of ocean coloring to itÂ Â

now leave that to cool down to room temperatureÂ 
grab your cake and using a brand new toothbrushÂ Â

you can add some more ganache to give it a bitÂ 
more of a coral rocky texture for the underwaterÂ Â

area. for the bit above the water i'm going toÂ 
add some more milk chocolate ganache on top toÂ Â

make it look a bit more like rocks. Add a cake tinÂ 
lined with a cylinder of acetate over the top andÂ Â

pipe ganache around that bottom edge to help stopÂ 
it leaking. Now there's no way this is waterproofÂ Â

it's not silicon so i suggest that you add a smallÂ 
amount of jelly and put that in the fridge to setÂ Â

unless you want sticky jelly set throughout yourÂ 
whole fridge because it will have leaked out.Â Â

once it is set you can then pour in the rest ofÂ 
your jelly now if you want to add decorationsÂ Â

make sure you make them out of chocolate don't useÂ 
fondant because fondant doesn't like moisture it'sÂ Â

just going to go soft as Taylor found out whenÂ 
her fondant fish oozed out the side of her islandÂ Â

cake. The next day peel off the acetate and we canÂ 
see the most common fail which is cloudy water,Â Â

I mean it's okay but it's not great so if you getÂ 
to this point and you're not happy with it or ifÂ Â

your jelly's collapsed or any of those thingsÂ 
this is how you rescue it. Just remove the oceanÂ Â

it's just jelly after all it's fairly easy to peelÂ 
off. I'm happy with the consistency of this jellyÂ Â

it has a nice wobble to it still but it's stillÂ 
firm enough to hold its shape without a containerÂ Â

around it. Now the reason this isn't clear is theÂ 
jelly before it sets is pretty much mainly waterÂ Â

so it's dissolving some of the frosting ifÂ 
you think about if you had frosting in a bowlÂ Â

and you filled it up with water and you just leftÂ 
it there that water is going to start to dissolveÂ Â

that frosting and it's going to make itÂ 
cloudy so the secret to stop that happeningÂ Â

is to get everything ready again have your acetateÂ 
there and your metal cake tin and then put it inÂ Â

the freezer not the fridge it needs to go in theÂ 
freezer for at least two hours. Now make sureÂ Â

your jelly liquid is completely cold not warmÂ 
it needs to be at that point where if you putÂ Â

it in the fridge it would set fairly quickly nowÂ 
and then drizzle it all over the surface of theÂ Â

cake that is going to be under the water and whatÂ 
we're doing here is just getting a layer of jellyÂ Â

just a thin layer to set all over the frosting soÂ 
it creates a barrier between the cake and the restÂ Â

of the jelly. Okay put that back in the freezerÂ 
for 15 minutes to make sure it's definitely setÂ Â

and then slowly add the rest of the jellyÂ 
mixture letting it run down the acetate soÂ Â

it's not pounding onto the frosting and mixingÂ 
it together and then just put that in the fridgeÂ Â

to set which will take at least four hours.Â 
Now that it's set we can take off the acetateÂ Â

and that's what we're after clear blue waterÂ 
that reminds me of the water that we saw inÂ Â

Dubrovnik ğŸ‡­ğŸ‡· it almost looked like the boatsÂ 
were floating in mid-air the water was soÂ Â

crystal clear. Add some plastic wrap to protectÂ 
the top and decorate your island i'm using coconutÂ Â

colored with green food coloring just pop someÂ 
of that where you want it. Then dab on some blackÂ Â

food coloring, just to add a little bit moreÂ 
shading and crush a biscuit to make your sandÂ Â

and you can add that to the little beach areaÂ 
that we've got there. Remove your plastic add someÂ Â

squiggles of white food coloring and then justÂ 
blend those back a little bit with a bit of waterÂ Â

and there you have an island cake rescued andÂ 
ready to go. At number three is a tsunami cakeÂ Â

otherwise known as the pull me up cake as far asÂ 
i can tell they started in cafes in Taiwan as theÂ Â

boba lava cake and the first youtube video aboutÂ 
it was by wendy back in 2018 quickly followed byÂ Â

lots of others and because these are served atÂ 
the table you have to get it right first time soÂ Â

there are plenty of fails! So let me do a heap ofÂ 
experiments for you so that you have more hope ofÂ Â

getting this right first time. The main problemÂ 
people seem to be having with the bobba cake wasÂ Â

whipping the cream too much it needs to be thinnerÂ 
than this see how it's holding its shape it's notÂ Â

flowing it's not going to flow off the cake. theÂ 
same thing will happen if you add the topping tooÂ Â

early the cake will absorb the moisture from theÂ 
cream and then it will just be too thick and thenÂ Â

when you lift up the acetate it just sits on topÂ 
it doesn't flow over which is what it's supposedÂ Â

to do. Now let's try that with two cups of creamÂ 
not whipped as firmly see how this is runny as IÂ Â

put it on top i mean it's not just liquid i haveÂ 
whipped it but it's definitely not got peaks yet.Â Â

I don't have any of the black tapioca or boba soÂ 
i'm just using fruit instead here it goes withÂ Â

two cups of cream it flows down over theÂ 
edge like it's supposed to but there's justÂ Â

not enough of it let's try that with threeÂ 
cups of cream this time and some edibleÂ Â

glitter and some other toppings on top ofÂ 
that okay here it goes three cups of cream...

that's about right it didn't cover everywhere butÂ 
i don't think you want any more cream than that.Â Â

As this cake kind of made it across to westernÂ 
countries people started using sweeter toppingsÂ Â

like ganache and if you pour that straight on itÂ 
will run down between the cake and the acetateÂ Â

so to solve that problem you need to frostÂ 
the cake first and then instead of puttingÂ Â

the acetate around the outside put it onÂ 
top of the cake and push it in slightly.Â Â

The next issue is the quantity how much to addÂ 
because this is completely different to creamÂ Â

here i'm adding one cup of ganache and some edibleÂ 
glitter on top pull up the acetate and it everÂ Â

so slowly goes over the sides of the cake i'mÂ 
gonna speed this up that took four minutes andÂ Â

it's not enough to cover the cake so let's tryÂ 
two cups of ganache instead of one here we go

well it's pretty but it also makes a huge mess!Â 
Now if you've got a keen eye for observation youÂ Â

may have noticed the difference in consistencyÂ 
between those two ganaches ganache can be thickerÂ Â

or thinner depending on the ratio of cream toÂ 
chocolate but these two were exactly the same andÂ Â

I'll put the recipe for that on my website for youÂ 
so what's making one thicker and one thinner? It'sÂ Â

just the temperature the cooler the ganache theÂ 
thicker it will be here's a ganache that has justÂ Â

been made and it's really really runny and thisÂ 
is the same ganache once it had been left at roomÂ Â

temperature i used it on the Thomas cake. so let'sÂ 
try one cup with the runnier ganache here it goesÂ Â

it certainly drips down fasterÂ 
than one cup of thick ganacheÂ Â

but it's still not enough to cover yourÂ 
cake so let's try one and a half cups...

that quantity was better, let's try oneÂ 
and a half cups again just to be sureÂ Â

that quantity seems to work as long as you haveÂ 
a large cake stand or a plate to catch all theÂ Â

stuff that runs off. Personally I don't love theÂ 
look of lava cakes but if you want to make themÂ Â

at least you've got a bit more ofÂ 
an idea of how much you need to add.Â Â
